G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 because the amount in controversy does not exceed the jurisdictional limit of the District Court.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord may not directly or indirectly interfere with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the leased premises.

105 C.M.R. 410.351.proposition: Defendant’s conduct also violates 105 C.M.R. 410.351 and 105 C.M.R. 410.750, which require that electrical facilities be maintained in good working order—a condition of lawful occupancy under G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L.

105 C.M.R. 410.750.proposition: Defendant’s conduct also violates 105 C.M.R. 410.351 and 105 C.M.R. 410.750, which require that electrical facilities be maintained in good working order—a condition of lawful occupancy under G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L.

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7\u00a7 127A\u2013127L.proposition: Defendant’s conduct also violates 105 C.M.R. 410.351 and 105 C.M.R. 410.750, which require that electrical facilities be maintained in good working order—a condition of lawful occupancy under G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L.

Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.raw_text: Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.proposition: Massachusetts law imposes upon landlords an implied covenant that tenants shall have the right to quiet enjoyment.
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.support_reasoning: This concurring/dissenting opinion is focused on implied warranty of habitability and code-compliance, not expressly on an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment. However, Hemingway as a whole is the seminal Massachusetts case modernizing landlord-tenant law and recognizing implied contractual obligations running from landlord to tenant in residential leases. That doctrinal shift underlies and supports later Massachusetts recognition that leases contain an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, so the case is supportive but only indirectly and not by explicit holding in the quoted portion.
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: "As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tenant..."

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: Massachusetts law imposes upon landlords an implied covenant that tenants shall have the right to quiet enjoyment.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly refers to the tenants’ “implied covenant” or “implied warranty” of quiet enjoyment and analyzes whether the landlords breached that covenant, treating it as a standard, existing obligation under Massachusetts landlord‑tenant law. Although the case’s main issue is attribution of noise and constructive eviction, the court clearly proceeds on the premise that such an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment exists in Massachusetts leases, thereby supporting the proposition.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “The judge found that the tenants were ‘very substantially deprived’ of quiet enjoyment of their leased premises ‘for a substantial time’ (emphasis original). He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances… The landlords argue that they did not violate the tenants’ implied covenant of quiet enjoyment because they are not chargeable with the noise from the lounge.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: The persistent loss of electricity constitutes a serious defect that materially impairs the tenant’s use of the property and violates the covenant.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The case concerns repeated flooding and sewage in the tenant’s apartment as violations of the warranty of habitability and covenant of quiet enjoyment; it does not address electricity or loss of electrical service. The court’s discussion of ‘essential services’ in G.L. c. 186, § 14, lists utilities including light and power generally, but there is no holding or reasoning specifically about persistent loss of electricity as a serious defect. Using this case to support that specific electricity proposition would be an analogy, not direct authority.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “Section 14 belongs to a body of statutes establishing tenants’ remedies against landlords who fail to provide safe and sanitary housing… These statutes are designed to facilitate enforcement of State housing regulations and to provide relief for tenants deprived of decent homes… unsanitary conditions in an apartment cause harm to the occupants whether the landlord has acted intentionally, negligently, or innocently… In the present case… Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

Chalmers v. Commonwealth Realty Trust, 3.raw_text: Chalmers v. Commonwealth Realty Trust, 386 Mass. 540 (1982)
Chalmers v. Commonwealth Realty Trust, 3.proposition: Defendant’s inaction, despite notice, is an “indirect act” of interference explicitly covered by § 14.
Chalmers v. Commonwealth Realty Trust, 3.support_reasoning: The provided opinion is Payton v. Abbott Labs, not Chalmers v. Commonwealth Realty Trust, and it concerns tort law issues related to DES liability and emotional distress—not any interpretation of G.L. c. 186, § 14 or the concept of an ‘indirect act’ of interference by inaction after notice. Nowhere does the court discuss landlord-tenant interference, statutory ‘indirect acts,’ or liability based on failure to act after notice. Therefore, this case does not support the proposition that a defendant’s inaction despite notice is an ‘indirect act’ of interference under § 14.

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: Landlords are strictly liable under § 14 for violations once notice is provided.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly rejects imposing strict liability on landlords under G.L. c. 186, § 14 based solely on a statutory violation and instead requires at least negligent conduct plus notice or reason to know of the condition. It distinguishes the strict liability scheme of the lead paint statute from § 14 and refuses to treat a statutory violation as automatically triggering § 14 liability or attorneys’ fees. Thus it contradicts, rather than supports, the proposition that landlords are strictly liable under § 14 once notice is provided.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”

Lowery v. Robbins, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982.raw_text: Lowery v. Robbins, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)
Lowery v. Robbins, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982.proposition: Landlords are strictly liable under § 14 for violations once notice is provided.
Lowery v. Robbins, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982.support_reasoning: The case holds that under G.L. c. 186, § 14, liability for breach of quiet enjoyment does not depend on the landlord’s intent or financial ability, focusing instead on whether the landlord’s conduct caused an interruption of the tenant’s rights. It does not discuss any requirement of prior "notice" to trigger liability or describe the liability as "strict" in the sense of arising automatically upon notice. The opinion is about the irrelevance of intent/financial inability, not about notice-based strict liability.
Lowery v. Robbins, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982.relevant_excerpt: It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather "the landlords conduct, and not his intentions, is control[ling]." Blackett v. Olanoff, supra at 716. Thus, as suggested by the language of the statute itself (see Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 99-100 [1982]), liability will be imposed "whenever the 'natural and probable consequence' of [the] landlords action [is] interruption of the tenants rights."

Haddad v. Giacosa, 37 Mass. App. Ct. 547.raw_text: Haddad v. Giacosa, 37 Mass. App. Ct. 547 (1994)
Haddad v. Giacosa, 37 Mass. App. Ct. 547.proposition: Courts have held that failure to maintain essential utilities, even when caused by neglect rather than intent, breaches quiet enjoyment.
Haddad v. Giacosa, 37 Mass. App. Ct. 547.support_reasoning: The opinion in Haddad v. Giacosa concerns paternity and the interpretation of G.L. c. 209C, including who may bring paternity actions and issues of laches. It does not address landlord‑tenant law, quiet enjoyment, or the maintenance of utilities. Therefore it provides no authority for the proposition that failure to maintain essential utilities, even if due to neglect rather than intent, breaches quiet enjoyment.
Haddad v. Giacosa, 37 Mass. App. Ct. 547.relevant_excerpt: From the language of c. 209C and its context, it appears that the authority so conferred is exclusive. . . . Even if we conclude the Probate Court could decide the issues under its general equity jurisdiction (G. L. c. 215, § 6) . . . the plaintiff’s claim would be barred by the defense of laches.

Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.proposition: Courts have held that failure to maintain essential utilities, even when caused by neglect rather than intent, breaches quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The case does deal with breach of quiet enjoyment based on the landlord’s omissions, but it concerns failure to address criminal drug activity and remove nontenants, not failure to maintain essential utilities. The opinion does not discuss utilities at all, nor does it suggest that negligent non-maintenance of utilities, as opposed to intentional shutoff, constitutes a breach of quiet enjoyment. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for the specific proposition about essential utilities and neglect.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “In analyzing whether there is a breach of the covenant, we examine the landlord’s conduct and not his intentions. Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716 (1977). Thus, a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’ … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies….”}

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987)
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: Courts have held that failure to maintain essential utilities, even when caused by neglect rather than intent, breaches quiet enjoyment.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses utilities only to interpret the State Sanitary Code requirement that any transfer of the obligation to supply heat and hot water must be in a written agreement. It does not analyze quiet enjoyment at all, nor does it address whether a landlord’s neglect leading to failure to maintain essential utilities constitutes a breach of quiet enjoyment. Therefore it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt: “The State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. §§ 410.190 and 410.201 (1983), provides that the owner of a dwelling ‘shall’ supply heat and hot water ‘except and to the extent that the occupant is required to supply the fuel under a written letting agreement.’ … The plain and unambiguous language of the regulation indicates that a writing is required when the obligation to provide heat and hot water is transferred to the tenant.”

Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Cor.raw_text: Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp., 340 Mass. 124 (1959)
Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Cor.proposition: Defendant’s delay of more than thirty days without repair violates Massachusetts State Sanitary Code and amounts to a constructive partial eviction.
Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Cor.case_name: Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp.
Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Cor.support_reasoning: The opinion does support that a landlord’s serious, inexcusable failure to provide essential services (heat, power, elevator) can constitute a constructive eviction, but it does not mention the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code or any specific thirty‑day repair period. The court’s analysis is framed entirely in terms of breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and constructive eviction, not statutory violation based on a defined time for repair. Thus, relying on this case to show that a delay of more than thirty days violates the State Sanitary Code and thereby constitutes constructive partial eviction misstates its holding.
Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Cor.relevant_excerpt: “Failure to furnish such services, at least if serious in extent and not excusable, deprives the lessee of a vital part of what the landlord knows the lessee must have in order to carry on his business. Such a failure constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment… and ‘enables the lessee to recover the damages caused to him thereby and also provides the lessee with the defense of "constructive eviction" (if he removes from the premises).’ … Such failure was a material breach of the lease and could be taken by Burt by abandoning the premises as a constructive eviction.”

Massachusetts State Sanitary Code.proposition: Defendant’s delay of more than thirty days without repair violates Massachusetts State Sanitary Code and amounts to a constructive partial eviction.
